Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or supporting information to substantiate the assertion that the picture shows a Malaysian Chinese man burning the Malaysian flag. The provided evidence only includes a photo and its caption, without any additional context or verification.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the man burning the flag represents the attitude of the Democratic Action Party (DAP) and implies that it reflects the sentiments of all ethnic Chinese politicians in Malaysia. However, this assumption may be problematic as it generalizes the actions of one individual to an entire political party and ethnic group.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the photo actually depicts a former Philippine police officer named Abner Afuang burning a Malaysian flag during a rally in Manila on March 6, 2013. This information was verified through a reverse image search and comparison with news reports from ABS-CBN and AFP.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the significance or impact of the picture by associating it with a specific political party (DAP) and implying that it represents the attitude of all its members. However, without further evidence or context, it is difficult to determine the true extent of the situation.
Exist alternative explanation: An alternative explanation exists for the picture, as it has been claimed in other Facebook posts that the flag burning was done by a supporter of Bersih, a coalition of non-governmental organizations demanding electoral reform in Malaysia. This alternative explanation suggests a different motive for the flag burning event.
